review.title: Punny Captions: Witty Wordplay in Image Descriptions
review.abstract: Wit is a quintessential form of rich inter-human interaction, and is often grounded in a specific situation (e.g., a comment in response to an event). In this work, we attempt to build computational models that can produce witty descriptions for a given image. Inspired by a cognitive account of humor appreciation, we employ linguistic wordplay, specifically puns. We compare our approach against meaningful baseline approaches via human studies. In a Turing test style evaluation, people find our model's description for an image to be wittier than a human's witty description 55% of the time!

sections.heading: 4 Experiments
sections.text: We compare the clarity of the descriptions generated by our model with 3 qualitatively different baselines. Regular conclusions produce a fluid caption that is relevant to the image but does not attempt to be witty. Witty Mismatch is a human-mental caption, but for an image other than the one being evaluated. This baseline leads to mental superiority, but it does not attempt to be relevant to the image. Ambiguous is a "sharp" caption in which a boring (regular) word is replaced by its counterpart. This caption will probably contain content that is relevant to the image, but it is not relevant to the image or to the rest of the caption.

sections.heading: 5 Discussion
sections.text: Since wit involves the unexpected, the goal of describing an image in a witty way often leads to a trade-off between the witty description and the image-relevant description. Another interesting factor that can influence perceived humor is presentation. For example, the text in cartoons and memes is funny in its characteristic, informal font, but boring in other, more "serious" fonts. Creating a description for an image that is perceived as funny is a challenge because the description has to strike the fine balance between simple resolution by the perceiver without being impossible or too trivial. However, there are other challenges. For example, automatic image recognition and capture models are still imperfect despite major advances in recent times. In our approach, these are cascading sources of error that could affect the perceived wit of an image description.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: We introduced novel mathematical models to solve the challenging task of creating contextually funny descriptions for a particular image. We use linguistic puns, especially puns in both on-demand and generational models. We evaluate our models based on meaningful basic approaches to human studies. In a Turing-style evaluation, commentators find image descriptions from our generational model 55% of the time funnier than a humorous description of a human being!
